trial_identification.studytitle: Multi-centre audit of ACE inhibitor associated angioedema
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A retrospective case note audit of symptoms, signs and management of patients attending hospital accident and emergency departments with angioedema who are currently taking an ACE inhibitor

interventions.interventions: All patients included in the audit will have been exposed to an ACE inhibitor medication as part of their routine treatment. There will be no additional exposures as part of the conduct of the study. The audit is of patients presenting to hospital emergency departments with angioedema between Jan 2008 and Dec 2010. The occurance of angioedema is the outcome being observed.

primaryOutcome.outcome:
symptoms - time of onset of angioedema, localisation of angioedema, any evidence of airway impairment.
Angioedema is detected by physical findings on clinical examination. These will be identified in the clinical record and will be found on case note review.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: at time of presentation to the hospital accident and emergency department

secondaryOutcome.outcome: treatment used - adrenaline, antihistamines, steroids, need for intubation or tracheostomy
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at time of presentation to hospital

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
Angioedema - ICD 9 Code 995.1, or ICD 10 Code T 78.3
must be on an ACE inhibior

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: University Drive, Bedford Park South Australia 5041

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This is an audit of patients who present to hospital with angioedema (swelling around the head and neck) associated with the use of a common blood pressure medication, the ACE inhibitors. The purpose is to try to determine how frequently this problem occurs across a range of hospitals, and also, to provide more information to enable an estimation of the proportion of cases where there is serious concern (ie threatened or real airway obstruction or death).
ethicsAndSummary.publication:
Multicentre audit of ACE inhibitor associated angioedema
Australian Family Physician 2015;44(8):579-583
Jimit Ghandi, Rachel Jones, David Teubner and Genevieve Gabb

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Royal Adelaide Hospital Research Ethics committee
